thread.title: Tourists will go to the moon with SpaceX
thread.title_full: Tourists will go to the moon with SpaceX

title: Tourists will go to the moon with SpaceX
text:
Tourists will go to the moon with SpaceX Last updated 10:58, February 28 2017 REUTERS/JOE SKIPPER 
Two people have paid for a private mission around the moon in 2018 with SpaceX 
SpaceX says two people have paid for a private mission around the moon in 2018. SpaceX founder Elon Musk said the mission would take approximately a week. 
There will be no landing on the surface. 
"This presents an opportunity for humans to return to deep space for the first time in 45 years and they will travel faster and further into the Solar System than any before them," the company said in a statement. NASA 
Astronaut Buzz Aldrin Jr walks on the surface of the moon in 1969. 
READ MORE: 
The individuals will travel in the Dragon 2 capsule - the same spacecraft used to bring supplies to the International Space Station. SpaceX said the people paid "a significant amount of money" for the moon trip. — Elon Musk (@elonmusk) February 27, 2017 
Lift-off will be from Kennedy Space Center's historic Pad 39A near Cape Canaveral – the same launch pad used by the Apollo program for its lunar missions. 
"Like the Apollo astronauts before them, these individuals will travel into space carrying the hopes and dreams of all humankind, driven by the universal human spirit of exploration," SpaceX said. 
The company suffered a blow when its Falcon 9 rocket exploded while being fuelled on a launch pad at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station last year. 
No one was on board the rocket, and there were no injuries. But the blast touched off a massive fireball and caused extensive damage, including the loss of a commercial satellite.
